head.supplied: ¶ I should be very pleased if you could procure the fruits of ¶ Trichosanthes holtzei ¶ (the Cucurbitacea with the almost kidney-shaped leaves and the white-fringed flowers), so that I can give a ...

div.p: GRG 19/391, Public Library, Museum & Art Gallery, State Records of South Australia, Adelaide.

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

note.p: Undated fragment. The dating to December 1886 is based on M's describing Trichosanthes holtzei in B86.12.01 but noting as he did so that he had not yet seen the fruit. See also M to M. Holtze, 3 December 1886 (in this edition as 86-12-03b), and M to M. Holtze, 12 December 1886. However, see also M to M. Holtze, 24 January 1885.

p.seg: Es wäre mir sehr lieb, wenn Sie die Früchte von Trichosanthes Holtzei (die Cucurbitacea mit fast nierenförmigen Blättern u. weissen gefranzten

p.style: font-family: Geneva; margin-left: 0.3335in; margin-right: 0in; text-indent: -0.3335in; font-size: 9pt;

p.seg: Blumen) liefern könnten, damit ich eine
Beschreibung geben kann. Wenn man von neuen Pflanzen die Früchte nicht hat, ist immer die Gefahr, dass man sie in ein unrichtiges genus stellt!
Ich denke mir, dass Sie auch gelegentlich noch manche Wasserpflanzen (

) dort im Flusse finden werden; selbst die allerkleinsten Wasserpflanzen, wie Entenflos, würden willkommen sein. Auch von der Eucalyptus blumigen Eugenia hätte ich gern die reife Frucht diesen Sommer.

div.p: I should be very pleased if you could procure the fruits of Trichosanthes holtzei (the Cucurbitacea with the almost kidney-shaped leaves and the white-fringed flowers), so that I can give a complete description. If one does not have the fruit of new plants, there is always the danger that one places them in the incorrect genus!

I imagine that occasionally you will still find many an aquatic plant ( floating ) in the river there. Even the very smallest aquatic plants such as duck weed would be welcome. I should also very much like to have the ripe fruit this summer of the Eugenia with the Eucalyptus -like flowers.
See also M to M. Holtze, 20 February 1886, and M to M. Holtze, 21 March 1886.
